cheatsheetvideos.quote: David Got help for his Class M using our Cheat sheet!
Jose explains how the motorcycle cheat sheet helped him pass his written exam.

questions.question: When riding in a group, it is best to put inexperienced riders near the front because:
questions.answerA: Experienced riders can more easily keep an eye on them.
questions.answerB: They will get lost if they are leading.
questions.answerC: They may slow the group down as the leaders.
questions.answerD: They will ride too fast in any other position.
questions.explanation: In a group, less experienced riders should ride toward the front, just behind the leader, so more experienced riders can easily watch them.

questions.question: When passing parked cars, which part of the lane should you usually use?
questions.answerA: The left portion of the lane
questions.answerB: The center portion of the lane
questions.answerC: The right portion of the lane
questions.answerD: Either the left or right portion of the lane
questions.explanation: When passing a row of parked cars, it is often safest to ride in the left portion of your lane. Riding in the left portion will keep you farthest from any opening car doors, people stepping out from between cars, and cars pulling out of parking spaces.

questions.question: Where is the clutch lever usually located?
questions.answerC: Near the left footrest
questions.answerD: Near the right footrest
questions.explanation: The clutch lever of a motorcycle is usually located on the left handgrip.

questions.question: If your front wheel begins to skid, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the front brake engaged and ride out the skid.
questions.answerB: Keep the front brake engaged and release the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Immediately release and re-engage the front brake.
questions.answerD: Release the front brake and increase the pressure on the rear brake.
questions.explanation: If your front wheel locks while braking, you should release the front brake immediately and completely before re-applying it smoothly.

questions.question: If another driver is following you too closely, it is best to:
questions.answerB: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerC: Speed up.
questions.answerD: Get off the roadway.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to get them in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Increasing your speed may only encourage the driver to tailgate you at a higher speed.

questions.question: As weight transfers to the front of your bike while you are braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Gradually increase pressure to the front brake.
questions.answerC: Not worry. The weight transfer will not have an effect on your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Try to lock the front tire.
questions.explanation: While you are braking, gradually increase the amount of pressure applied to the front brake lever as the weight of the bike is transferred forward to the front tire.

questions.question: What can you do to increase your chances of being seen at an intersection?
questions.answerB: Swerve within your lane to draw attention to your motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Raise your arms.
questions.answerD: Avoid using your brakes.
questions.explanation: To increase your chances of being seen at an intersection, use your headlight and ride in a lane position that creates the best view of oncoming traffic. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle that allows you to take evasive action.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should position themselves:
questions.answerA: In the front of the group.
questions.answerC: Close to the back of the group.
questions.answerD: At the tail end of the group.
questions.explanation: In a group of motorcyclists, less experienced riders should be positioned toward the front, just behind the leader. This ensures that they will not have to chase after the rest of the group. This positioning also allows them to be watched from behind by more experienced riders.

questions.question: To make a quick stop on wet pavement, you should:
questions.answerC: Use both brakes.
questions.explanation: Use both brakes if you must make a quick stop on a slippery surface. The front brake is safe to use on a slippery surface if applied gradually to prevent locking.

questions.question: A three-wheeled motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Handles curves about the same as a two-wheeled motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Handles curves differently than a two-wheeled motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Should not be operated in curves.
questions.answerD: Should use the shoulder when taking a curve.
questions.explanation: The cornering characteristics of a three-wheeled motorcycle or a motorcycle with a sidecar differ from those of a two-wheeled motorcycle.

questions.question: When braking on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerC: Use both brakes.
questions.answerD: Not use any brakes, but downshift.
questions.explanation: To ride safely on a slippery surface, you should reduce your speed and avoid making sudden moves. Use both brakes if you must slow down or stop.

questions.question: Swerving a motorcycle:
questions.answerC: Is a slow maneuver.
questions.answerD: Should be done to avoid a hazard on a slippery road.
questions.explanation: Swerving is a quick maneuver that requires a lot of traction in order to be safely executed. Making sudden moves, such as swerving, on slippery surfaces should be avoided.

questions.question: When approaching a blind intersection with a stop sign, riders should:
questions.answerA: Stop at the stop sign then proceed through the intersection.
questions.answerB: Ignore the stop sign and move forward to get a better look.
questions.answerC: Stop at the stop sign before moving forward to improve their view of cross traffic.
questions.answerD: Proceed through the intersection without stopping.
questions.explanation: When approaching a blind intersection that is controlled by a stop line or stop sign, you must first stop where indicated. You may then edge forward and stop again just short of where the cross traffic lane meets your lane. From that position, lean your body forward and look around buildings, parked cars, or bushes to see if anything is approaching. Make sure your front wheel stays out of the crossroad while you are looking.

questions.question: The middle portion of the lane usually contains an oily strip. You should:
questions.answerA: Try to avoid the oily strip when it is raining.
questions.answerB: Ride only on the oily strip, as it provides increased traction.
questions.answerC: Avoid the entire center portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Not worry about oil or other items in a lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars and trucks build up in the center of each lane. Unless the road is wet, this strip usually still provides enough traction more a motorcycle to operate safely. The strip is generally narrow enough that you can ride to either side of it and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: A windshield:
questions.answerA: Is a good substitute for a face shield.
questions.answerB: Does not completely protect your eyes from the wind.
questions.answerC: Is required on all motorcycles.
questions.answerD: Should be used on windy days.
questions.explanation: A windshield is not an adequate substitute for the protection offered by goggles or a face shield. Most windshields will not protect your eyes from the wind.

questions.question: When looking for a protective jacket or pair of pants, you should look for:
questions.answerC: Items made of light materials.
questions.answerD: Items that are darkly-colored.
questions.explanation: It is safest to wear long pants and a jacket to fully cover your arms and legs while riding. Clothing made of leather can provide the highest level of protection.

questions.question: To swerve, you should:
questions.answerC: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerD: Press the handgrip in the opposite direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: To swerve, apply a small amount of pressure to the handgrip located on the side of your intended direction of escape. To swerve to the left, press the left handgrip, then press the right to recover. To swerve to the right, press the right handgrip, then the left.

questions.question: On a two-lane highway, motorcycle riders in a group should pass:
questions.answerC: In a single-file line.
questions.answerD: On the shoulder.
questions.explanation: On a two-lane road, a group of motorcycle riders should pass one at a time. The lead rider should complete the pass before the next rider begins.

questions.question: Convex mirrors make cars seem:
questions.answerC: Faster.
questions.answerD: Narrower.
questions.explanation: Rounded, or convex, mirrors provide a wider view of the road than flat mirrors, but they also make objects seem farther away than they actually are.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Not use your turn signals when changing lanes.
questions.answerC: Watch about five feet ahead of your motorcycle while riding.
questions.answerD: Always be ready to use crash-avoidance techniques.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle. Always be ready to avoid an unexpected hazard.

questions.question: Crashes are more likely to occur among:
questions.answerC: Those familiar with their motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Those who have completed a safety course.
questions.explanation: Crashes are the most likely to occur for untrained, beginning riders who are unfamiliar with their motorcycle.

questions.question: When you ride, the best gear to wear is:
questions.answerA: Any gear that helps to protect you.
questions.answerC: Gear that looks good.
questions.answerD: Any gear that fits.
questions.explanation: You should wear gear that helps protect you while you ride. It is best to wear a DOT-approved helmet, face or eye protection, and protective clothing.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should tell them to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Get on the motorcycle after the engine has been started.
questions.answerB: Sit as far forward as they can without crowding you.
questions.answerC: Hold firmly onto your waist, hips, or belt.
questions.answerD: Feel free to talk whenever they want.
questions.explanation: To help keep the operator focused on riding, passengers should avoid unnecessary conversation or movement. Passengers should get on a motorcycle only after the engine has been started. They should sit as far forward as they can without crowding the operator and hold firmly onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: When being passed by another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the left portion of your lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the center portion of your lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of your lane.
questions.answerD: Try to get onto the shoulder.
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is generally safest to ride in the center portion of your lane. Riding on the side of the lane nearest the passing driver increases the danger of a collision, and riding on the side farthest from the passing driver may tempt them to return to your lane too soon.

questions.question: To reduce your reaction time, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride slower than the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Cover the clutch and the brakes.
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral when slowing.
questions.answerD: Pull in the clutch when turning.
questions.explanation: To help reduce your reaction time, you should cover the clutch and brakes. This is especially helpful when riding through areas where potential hazards are likely.

questions.question: To lean the motorcycle for a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: Press the handgrip in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.answerC: Apply the front brake.
questions.answerD: Apply the rear brake.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle needs to lean in order to turn. To make this happen, press on the handgrip in the direction you want to turn.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Not wear a jacket if it's warm out.
questions.answerB: Always wear a jacket, even if it’s warm out.
questions.answerC: Wear shorts in warm weather.
questions.answerD: Not be concerned about long shoelaces.
questions.explanation: For your protection, you should always wear a long-sleeved jacket made of appropriate material when riding. This is true even in warm weather because wearing a jacket is important to help prevent dehydration. You should also always wear long pants, and tuck in the laces of your footwear to prevent them from catching on the motorcycle.

questions.question: Most motorcycles have rounded, or convex, mirrors. These mirrors:
questions.answerA: Are easy to get used to right away.
questions.answerB: Make cars seem closer than they actually are.
questions.answerC: Provide a narrow view of the road.
questions.answerD: Make cars seem farther away than they actually are.
questions.explanation: In comparison to flat mirrors, convex mirrors provide a wider view of the road behind you. They also make objects seem farther away than they actually are. You should practice judging distances in convex mirrors if you are not used to them.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger or cargo:
questions.answerA: It may take less time to accelerate, but more time to stop.
questions.answerB: It may take more time to accelerate and stop.
questions.answerC: It may take more time to accelerate, but less time to stop.
questions.answerD: It may take less time to accelerate and stop.
questions.explanation: Because of the additional weight added by cargo or a passenger, motorcycles may take longer to accelerate and stop than they would if only transporting the operator.

questions.question: To swerve correctly:
questions.answerC: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerD: Press the handgrip in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.explanation: To execute a swerve, press the handgrip on the side of your desired turn. Press on the opposite handgrip to return to your original direction after you are clear of the hazard.

questions.question: In a slow, tight turn, the rider should:
questions.answerA: Counterbalance the leaning motorcycle by keeping their body upright.
questions.answerB: Lean at the same angle as the motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Lean in the opposite direction of the motorcycle and the turn.
questions.answerD: Counterbalance their leaning body by keeping the motorcycle upright.
questions.explanation: When taking normal turns, lean at the same angle as your motorcycle. However, in slow, tight turns, you should counterbalance the leaning motorcycle by keeping your body upright.

questions.question: You should completely check your motorcycle:
questions.answerC: Once a month.
questions.answerD: Once a year.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle requires more frequent attention than a car. Make a complete check of your motorcycle before every ride.

questions.question: If the throttle is stuck, you should:
questions.answerC: Twist the throttle back and forth several times.
questions.answerD: Not try to twist the throttle.
questions.explanation: If your throttle becomes stuck, try twisting it back and forth several times. If this does not free your throttle, immediately operate the engine cut-off switch and pull in the clutch at the same time.

questions.question: When making a turn:
questions.answerA: There is less traction available for stopping.
questions.answerB: There is more traction available for stopping.
questions.answerC: Stopping is no different than making a stop on a straightaway.
questions.answerD: Stopping should never be attempted.
questions.explanation: It is possible to brake while turning, but it should be done with great care. When a motorcycle is leaning to turn, there is less traction available for stopping because some of the traction is being used for turning.

questions.question: A helmeted rider is _______ more likely to survive a crash than a rider not wearing a helmet.
questions.answerC: Six times
questions.answerD: 20 times
questions.explanation: No matter the speed, riders who are not wearing helmets are three times more likely to die from head injuries than riders who are wearing helmets at the time of a crash.

questions.question: When making normal stops, you should:
questions.answerC: Use both the front and rear brakes.
questions.answerD: Alternate between the front and rear brakes.
questions.explanation: Make it a habit to always use both brakes when slowing or stopping, even for normal, non-emergency stops.

questions.question: To control your motorcycle well, you should:
questions.answerA: Sit with your arms propping you up rather than steering.
questions.answerB: Keep your knees against the gas tank for balance.
questions.answerC: Allow your feet to hang off the footrests.
questions.answerD: Sit so far back that you must stretch to reach the handgrips.
questions.explanation: When riding, keep your knees against the gas tank to help maintain your balance in turns. Sit so that you can use your arms to steer rather than to prop yourself up. Sit far enough forward that your arms are slightly bent when you hold the handgrips, and keep your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: What does this hand signal mean?
questions.answerC: Right turn
questions.answerD: Backing up
questions.explanation: Instead of or in addition to mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is bent at the elbow and pointing upward, it means the operator plans to turn right or change lanes to the right.

questions.question: Because of their small size, motorcycles seem to be:
questions.answerA: Traveling faster than they actually are.
questions.answerB: Traveling more slowly than they actually are.
questions.answerC: Not moving when they actually are.
questions.answerD: Closer than they actually are.
questions.explanation: Because of their size, motorcycles may seem to be traveling faster than they actually are.

questions.question: Shifting to a lower gear produces an effect similar to:
questions.answerC: Swerving.
questions.answerD: Turning.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycles have a manual transmission. Downshifting to a lower gear will slow you down.

questions.question: Where is the rear brake pedal usually located?
questions.answerC: Near the left footrest
questions.answerD: Near the right footrest
questions.explanation: The rear brake of a motorcycle is usually controlled by a pedal near the right footrest.

questions.question: You’ll have a better chance of avoiding serious injury if you wear all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Ear buds.
questions.answerD: Protective clothing.
questions.explanation: To protect yourself against injury, you should wear a DOT-compliant helmet; face or eye protection; a jacket and long pants made of sturdy material; boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles; and gloves made of durable material.

questions.question: Your lane position should:
questions.answerA: Keep your intentions hidden from other drivers.
questions.answerB: Encourage other drivers to share your lane.
questions.answerC: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerD: Be close to the road signs.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: Which vest or jacket color would best help you to be seen?
questions.answerC: Silver
questions.answerD: Blue
questions.explanation: Wearing brightly-colored clothing while riding will increase your chances of being seen. Bright oranges, yellows, reds, or greens are best and are preferable to drab or dark colors.

questions.question: Riding gloves are often:
questions.answerC: Not pre-curved.
questions.answerD: Unsafe for the rider.
questions.explanation: Gloves designed for motorcycle riding are usually made of leather. In addition to improving your grip, gloves provide protection for a rider's hands and fingers.

questions.question: Drivers on an entrance ramp may not see you on the highway. What should you do to help an entering driver merge safely?
questions.answerA: Stay in your lane, as it is not your responsibility to be seen.
questions.answerB: Change to a lane away from the entrance ramp, if possible.
questions.answerC: Move to the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Weave within your lane to be more obvious to the entering driver.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision, always allow merging vehicles plenty of space to safely enter traffic. Change lanes away from the entrance ramp if there is room to do so safely. If there isn't another lane available, adjust your speed to open up space for the merging driver.

questions.question: Making eye contact with other drivers:
questions.answerA: Is the best way to know that they see you.
questions.answerB: Is not worth the effort it takes.
questions.answerC: Does not mean that they will yield to you when they should.
questions.answerD: Guarantees that they will yield to you.
questions.explanation: You should never take eye contact as a guarantee that a driver will properly yield to you. It is not uncommon for drivers to look directly at a motorcyclist but fail to register that they are there.

questions.question: When riding a three-wheeled motorcycle through a curve, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Stay in the center of the lane.
questions.answerB: Stay on the outside of the lane.
questions.answerC: Change your path as needed.
questions.answerD: Use the shoulder.
questions.explanation: The cornering characteristics of a three-wheeled motorcycle or a motorcycle with a sidecar differ from those of a two-wheeled motorcycle. The best path for a three-wheeler to take through a curve may not actually follow the curve. For example, you may need to move from the outside of the curve to the inside of the curve before straightening out your path.

questions.question: Extend your normal following distance when:
questions.answerB: Riding during the day under ideal conditions.
questions.answerC: There are two lanes of traffic moving in each direction.
questions.answerD: There is no reason to believe stopping will take longer than normal.
questions.explanation: An expanded space cushion is needed when riding in conditions that are less than ideal. If the road surface is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead, if you are traveling at night, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may be tempted to squeeze in front of you, you should expand your following distance.

questions.question: When riding near stopped or slow-moving cars, a motorcyclist should:
questions.answerA: Pull over and wait until traffic begins to move.
questions.answerB: Ride on the shoulder to get through the area as quickly as possible.
questions.answerC: Weave between the cars to get through the area as quickly as possible.
questions.answerD: Not weave between the cars.
questions.explanation: Riding between slowed or parked cars can leave you vulnerable to unexpected hazards, such as opening car doors or cars suddenly pulling into traffic. If a hazard arises, you will not have room to safely maneuver. Never travel on the shoulder of a road because other drivers will never expect you to be there.

questions.question: A larger cushion of space may not be necessary if:
questions.answerB: You cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you.
questions.answerC: Weather and traffic conditions are perfect.
questions.answerD: Traffic is heavy.
questions.explanation: Your following distance should be larger than usual when you are traveling under imperfect conditions. Increase your following distance if pavement is slippery, you can't see through the vehicle in front of you, or traffic is heavy.

questions.question: If in a no passing zone:
questions.answerA: A motorcycle may still pass another vehicle.
questions.answerB: A motorcycle is not allowed to pass another vehicle.
questions.answerC: A motorcycle may pass another vehicle if the pass can be completed before another vehicle approaches.
questions.answerD: A motorcycle may pass on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: Passing is prohibited in no passing zones. It is also prohibited to pass by riding off of the main-traveled portion of a roadway.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should:
questions.answerC: Start slowing later than usual.
questions.answerD: Try to squeeze into smaller gaps in traffic.
questions.explanation: The added weight of a passenger will affect the handling of your motorcycle. Expect your motorcycle to accelerate more slowly than usual, turn more slowly than usual, and require extra space to come to a complete stop. Ride more slowly, start slowing sooner when approaching a stop, open up a larger space cushion, and wait for larger gaps when crossing, entering, or merging into traffic.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a factor in determining blood alcohol content (BAC)?
questions.answerB: How fast the alcohol is consumed
questions.answerC: The drinker's body weight
questions.answerD: How often the drinker consumes alcohol
questions.explanation: The three major factors that affect a person's blood alcohol content (BAC) are the amount of alcohol consumed, how fast the alcohol was consumed, and the drinker's body weight. It is illegal and dangerous to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: If you are using an unfamiliar motorcycle, what should you do before riding?
questions.answerA: Ride like you would on your bike, since all bikes are about the same.
questions.answerB: Check the controls and shift pattern.
questions.answerC: Take the owner’s word that everything is in working order.
questions.answerD: Assume you know where all the controls are located.
questions.explanation: All motorcycles are slightly different, so you should check the controls and make sure you know the gear pattern before riding an unfamiliar motorcycle. Work the throttle, clutch, and brakes a few times prior to riding.

questions.question: When someone follows you too closely, you should:
questions.answerB: Not worry about them and just focus on the road in front of you.
questions.answerC: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder and let them pass.
questions.explanation: The best way to handle a tailgater is to change lanes and let them pass you. Speeding up may cause them to tailgate you at a higher speed, only increasing the danger. Never ride on the shoulder of a road because drivers will never expect you to be there and may leave the road suddenly.

questions.question: Many over-the-counter drugs:
questions.answerC: Only affect your riding if you drink along with taking the medication.
questions.answerD: Have the same effect on everyone.
questions.explanation: Like alcohol, many other drugs (including prescription medications, over-the-counter medications, and illegal drugs) have side effects that may impair your ability to ride safely.

questions.question: When you are being passed by another vehicle, which part of the lane should you ride in?
questions.answerC: The right
questions.answerD: It doesn’t matter.
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is generally safest to ride in the center portion of your lane. Riding on the side nearest the passing vehicle increases the risk of colliding with them. Riding on the side farthest from the passing vehicle is also dangerous, as it could tempt the driver to re-enter your lane before it is safe to do so.

questions.question: If you cannot avoid a slippery road, you should:
questions.answerA: Lean into the slippery section to maintain your balance.
questions.answerB: Maintain your speed to improve traction.
questions.answerC: Not worry about the road conditions.
questions.answerD: Keep your motorcycle upright and proceed as slowly as needed.
questions.explanation: It is best to entirely avoid slippery stretches of road. However, if there is no way to avoid such an area, keep your motorcycle upright and proceed as slowly as possible.

questions.question: When riding in a group, the best way to keep ranks close while maintaining an adequate safety cushion is to ride:
questions.answerC: In a single-file line.
questions.answerD: In a passing formation.
questions.explanation: A staggered formation is the best way to keep ranks close while still maintaining an adequate space cushion for all riders. Ride in a single-file line when riding in curves, turning, or entering or leaving a highway. Never ride side-by-side with another rider.

questions.question: The front brake is:
questions.answerC: Only to be used if the rear brake fails.
questions.answerD: Not to be used regularly.
questions.explanation: The front brake is safe to use as long as it is used properly. The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake, providing at least three-fourths of the total stopping power.

questions.question: To increase your chances of being seen at an intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to make eye contact with other drivers.
questions.answerC: Reduce your space cushion.
questions.answerD: Ride in a weaving pattern.
questions.explanation: To increase your chances of being seen at an intersection, leave your headlight turned on and ride in a lane position that most easily allows oncoming traffic to see you. Maintain a space cushion that allows you to take evasive action if necessary. Never assume that another driver sees you, even if you make eye contact with the driver.

questions.question: Which of the following provides the best protection?
questions.answerC: Goggles
questions.answerD: Face shield
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield provides protection for the wearer's entire face in the event of a crash. Goggles may protect someone's eyes, but not the rest of their face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for either.

questions.question: If you find your motorcycle being chased by a dog, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop until the animal loses interest.
questions.answerC: Ride alongside the animal.
questions.answerD: Approach the animal slowly, then speed up.
questions.explanation: If you are being chased by a dog, downshift and approach it slowly. Then, as you approach the dog, accelerate and leave it behind.

questions.question: Of the crashes involving both a motorcycle and a car, how many are caused by the driver failing to properly yield the right-of-way to the rider?
questions.answerC: Over 50 percent
questions.answerD: About 90 percent
questions.explanation: Of the crashes involving both a motorcycle and a car, more than half are caused by the driver failing to properly yield right-of-way to the rider.

questions.question: When stopping behind a vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop far behind the vehicle, then slowly creep up.
questions.answerC: Make a quick stop right behind the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Stay about four car lengths behind the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Stay well behind the vehicle in front of you, even if you are both stopped. The vehicle could back up unexpectedly, or you may need space to get out of the way of another vehicle bearing down on you from behind.

questions.question: Normally, you should maintain a following distance of:
questions.answerC: Three seconds.
questions.answerD: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, you should allow at least two seconds of distance between you and the vehicle ahead of you. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than ideal.

questions.question: When exiting a highway while riding in a group, which riding formation should be used?
questions.answerC: Paired up
questions.answerD: Riding three across a lane
questions.explanation: While a staggered formation is usually best for group riding, a group should switch into a single-file formation when taking curves, turning, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: If the front wheel locks, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue to hold the brake and the skid should end.
questions.answerB: Release the front brake and not use the front brake.
questions.answerC: Release the front brake and then quickly squeeze the front brake.
questions.answerD: Release the front brake immediately and re-apply the front brake smoothly.
questions.explanation: If your front wheel locks, immediately and completely release the front brake. Re-apply the brake smoothly.

questions.question: Riding alongside a car:
questions.answerB: Can place you in a blind spot.
questions.answerC: Is not an issue unless the roadway is wet.
questions.answerD: Can make driving easier for the other motorist.
questions.explanation: Riding directly alongside another vehicle is dangerous because it may place you in the driver's blind spot. Additionally, the vehicle will block your path of escape.

questions.question: When riding at night you should:
questions.answerC: Use the vehicle in front of you to help see.
questions.answerD: Wear tinted glasses.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision when riding at night, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use the headlights of vehicles ahead of you to see farther down the road. You should always be flexible about your lane position, especially when riding at night.

questions.question: If hazards are on your left, you should ride:
questions.answerA: In the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: In the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: In any portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: On the shoulder.
questions.explanation: When hazards exist to your left, it is often best to ride in the right portion of the lane. Be prepared to adjust your lane position as road and traffic conditions change.

questions.question: If you are feeling tired while riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep going and hope to wake up.
questions.answerC: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Get off the road and rest.
questions.explanation: You should avoid riding if you are tired. When making a long trip, take rest breaks at least every two hours to reduce the risk of becoming fatigued.

questions.question: If you are hit by a wind blast caused by a passing vehicle, you will have the most room for error if you are riding:
questions.answerA: In the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: In the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: In the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: On the shoulder.
questions.explanation: If you are in the middle portion of your lane, you will have the greatest room for error if your control is disrupted by a wind blast from a passing vehicle.

questions.question: When stopped behind another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Get as close as possible to the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Maintain a space cushion between your motorcycle and the other vehicle.
questions.answerC: Not use your rearview mirrors to monitor traffic behind you.
questions.answerD: Look for opportunities to squeeze through the stopped traffic.
questions.explanation: You should stay well behind the vehicle in front of you, even when you are both stopped. This will give you room to escape if the vehicle backs up unexpectedly or if another vehicle approaches too quickly from behind.

questions.question: Proper clothing for riding offers all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Protection from the cold.
questions.answerD: Discomfort.
questions.explanation: Proper clothing for riding can help protect you from injury in the event of a collision. It can also protect against routine hazards and discomforts, such as hot or cold weather.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if you have a windshield.
questions.answerC: Helps protect your whole face.
questions.answerD: Is less effective than goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield can help protect your whole face if you are involved in a crash. Goggles protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for googles or a face shield.

questions.question: Brightly-colored helmets:
questions.answerA: May make it easier for the wearer to be seen.
questions.answerC: Don’t help to improve a rider's visibility.
questions.answerD: Are not permitted.
questions.explanation: Choosing a brightly-colored helmet is recommended. Not only will the helmet protect you in the case of a crash, but the bright color of the helmet will help other road users see you.

questions.question: When riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders to look through turns.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Turn just your head and eyes to look through turns.
questions.explanation: Always look through a turn to where you want to go. Turn only your head to look, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: Goggles can:
questions.answerA: Protect your eyes and your face.
questions.answerB: Protect your face but not your eyes.
questions.answerC: Protect your eyes, but not your face.
questions.answerD: Not protect your face or eyes.
questions.explanation: Goggles can protect your eyes, but only a face shield can protect your entire face in a crash.

questions.question: Most crashes occur in broad daylight. To be more visible, you should:
questions.answerC: Ride without your headlight.
questions.answerD: Ride in a weaving pattern.
questions.explanation: Because most crashes happen in broad daylight, you should always wear brightly-colored clothing while riding, even during the day.

questions.question: What does this signal mean?
questions.answerC: Speed up
questions.answerD: Exit
questions.explanation: Hand signals are an important part of communication when riding in groups. This hand signal means "follow me."

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in an accident, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride within a foot of the vehicle in front of you.
questions.answerC: Signal only when you feel like it.
questions.answerD: Stay alert and be prepared to act to avoid a crash.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should be placed:
questions.answerA: In the front of the group.
questions.answerC: At the back of the group.
questions.answerD: Anywhere within the group.
questions.explanation: Inexperienced riders should ride near the front of a group, just behind the leader, so more experienced riders can keep an eye on them from behind.

questions.question: When entering a turn, a rider should:
questions.answerC: Move their shoulders to match the angle of the turn.
questions.answerD: Sit up as high as possible.
questions.explanation: Before entering a turn, a motorcyclist should reduce their speed by closing the throttle and, if necessary, applying both brakes.

questions.question: The front brake supplies approximately how much of a motorcycle's potential stopping power?
questions.answerC: About 70 percent
questions.answerD: About 95 percent
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake. The front brake supplies at least 70 percent of a motorcycle's total stopping power.

questions.question: A thorough check of your motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Is useless unless done by a mechanic.
questions.answerB: Should not be done before a ride.
questions.answerC: Should be done only after a ride.
questions.answerD: Can help you identify any mechanical defects or equipment failures.
questions.explanation: It is recommended that you thoroughly check your motorcycle before every ride. Doing this can help you identify mechanical defects or equipment failures that could endanger you.

questions.question: When changing lanes:
questions.answerA: There is no need to do a head check if you use your mirrors.
questions.answerB: Mirrors provide a full view of the road around your motorcycle.
questions.answerC: You should turn your head and look over your shoulder.
questions.answerD: You can assume drivers will properly respond to your turn signal.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles have blind spots just like any other vehicle. Always turn your head and look over your shoulder to check for traffic in your blind spot before changing lanes.

questions.question: If a tire goes flat while riding and you must stop, it is usually best to:
questions.answerB: Shift your weight toward the good tire.
questions.answerC: Brake on the good tire and steer to the side of the road.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes and stop quickly.
questions.explanation: If one of your tires fails, hold the handgrips firmly and begin to slow down by easing off the throttle while maintaining a straight course. If you must brake, gradually apply the brake of the tire that is still good, if you are sure of which tire that is. Edge toward the side of the road as you slow down, squeeze the clutch, and stop.

questions.question: Before changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head to check for vehicles in your blind spot.
questions.answerB: Rely on your mirrors to show you all of your surroundings.
questions.answerC: Point in the direction of the lane change.
questions.answerD: Speed up to get ahead of other vehicles.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles have blind spots, just like any other vehicle. You should always turn your head to check for traffic in your blind spot before changing lanes. Do not rely on your mirrors alone.

questions.question: When checking tires before a ride, you should look at all of the following except:
questions.answerC: General tread
questions.answerD: Shininess
questions.explanation: Before each ride, you should check the air pressure, tread, and general wear of your tires.

questions.question: When riding downhill or shifting into first gear, you may need to:
questions.answerA: Use your brakes to slow down before downshifting safely.
questions.answerC: Swerve to the left.
questions.answerD: Flash your brakes to ensure that drivers behind you know you are downshifting.
questions.explanation: Before shifting into a lower gear, make sure you are riding slowly enough to shift safely. Downshifting while going too fast may cause the motorcycle to lurch and the rear wheel to skid. When riding downhill or shifting into first gear, you may need to use the brakes to slow to a safe speed before downshifting.

questions.question: Reflective material on your helmet:
questions.answerC: Should only be used at night.
questions.answerD: Does not help you to be seen.
questions.explanation: Reflective material on a vest or on the sides of your helmet can make you more visible to other drivers and should be used both day and night.

questions.question: Generally, the body eliminates one alcoholic drink per hour. If a person consumed eight alcoholic drinks four hours ago, how many drinks likely remain in their body?
questions.answerC: Three drinks
questions.answerD: Four drinks
questions.explanation: The minimum number of drinks left in a person's system can be estimated by subtracting the number of hours since the last drink from the total number of drinks consumed. In this case, the alcohol content of about four drinks would remain.

questions.question: Which type of sign is yellow with black lettering or symbols?
questions.answerC: Regulatory
questions.answerD: Speed limit
questions.explanation: Warning signs are yellow with black lettering or symbols and provide important information to motorists about upcoming road conditions.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a possible cause of a wobble on your motorcycle?
questions.answerC: Unsuitable accessories
questions.answerD: Uneven road
questions.explanation: Most wobbles can be traced to improper loading, unsuitable accessories, or incorrect tire pressure. Do not try to accelerate out of a wobble.

questions.question: A group of riders should merge onto a highway in:
questions.answerC: Pairs.
questions.answerD: A pyramid formation.
questions.explanation: While a staggered formation is usually best under normal riding conditions, a group of riders should switch to a single-file formation when taking curves, turning, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: When stopping, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Grab at the front brake lever.
questions.answerB: Keep your knees against the gas tank and keep your eyes up.
questions.answerC: Apply increasing pressure to the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Only use the front brake.
questions.explanation: For maximum straight-line braking, you should apply the brakes smoothly and firmly. As more weight transfers forward, more will be more traction available at the front wheel, allowing you to apply the front brake with progressively increasing force while reducing the pressure being used on the rear brake. Keep your knees against the gas tank and your eyes up to help keep yourself moving in a straight line.

questions.question: A danger of riding next to a row of parked cars is:
questions.answerA: You may not find a parking spot.
questions.answerB: A driver may unexpectedly pull out from the row into your path.
questions.answerC: Others may be driving slowly while looking for a parking spot.
questions.answerD: The road may be uneven.
questions.explanation: Riding next to parked cars presents a number of potential dangers. A driver might pull out of parking space and into your path without looking. Car doors may be opened into your lane and pedestrians may step out from between cars.

questions.question: Hearing protection is:
questions.answerA: Not needed if you wear a helmet.
questions.answerB: Needed in addition to a helmet.
questions.answerC: Only needed on windy days.
questions.answerD: Not needed if you are carrying a passenger.
questions.explanation: Exposure to engine and wind noise can damage your hearing, even if you are wearing a helmet. Hearing protection can guard against this while still allowing you to hear essential sounds like horns and sirens.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a piece of protective clothing for a motorcycle rider?
questions.answerC: Gloves
questions.answerD: Sandals
questions.explanation: When riding, it is safest for a motorcyclist to wear a helmet, eye protection, a jacket, long pants, sturdy boots, and gloves.

questions.question: Which of the following is true?
questions.answerA: The front and rear brakes provide equal braking power.
questions.answerB: The front brake provides more braking power than the rear brake.
questions.answerC: The rear brake provides more braking power than the front brake.
questions.answerD: Only the front brake should be used when braking.
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear one, providing at least 70 percent of the total stopping power. Always use both brakes any time you slow or stop.

questions.question: When braking, you should:
questions.answerA: First apply the front brake, then the rear.
questions.answerB: First apply the rear brake, then the front.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.answerD: Use brakes in any order.
questions.explanation: Both brakes should be used at the same time whenever you slow or stop.

questions.question: When riding in curves, turning, or entering a highway, the best group formation is:
questions.answerC: Staggered.
questions.answerD: Passing.
questions.explanation: While riding in a staggered formation is generally the best option when traveling in a group, riders should move into a single-file line through curves, through turns, and when entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: When riding at night, how should your following distance compare to your following distance during the day?
questions.answerA: You should allow a longer following distance when following another vehicle at night.
questions.answerB: You should allow a shorter following distance when following another vehicle at night.
questions.answerC: You should always maintain the same following distance regardless of the time of day.
questions.answerD: Following distance really doesn’t matter.
questions.explanation: Distances are difficult to judge in the dark because visual cues (like shadows and light contrasts) can be missing or distorted. You should allow a longer following distance when riding at night than you do when riding during the day.

questions.question: In New Hampshire, a person who is age 21 or older with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of ______ is considered legally intoxicated.
questions.answerC: 0.06 percent
questions.answerD: 0.08 percent
questions.explanation: A person who is of legal drinking age with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher is considered legally intoxicated. It is both illegal and unsafe to ride a motorcycle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: Face shields and goggles:
questions.answerA: Will likely never need to be replaced.
questions.answerB: Will develop scratches and become brittle, requiring regular replacement.
questions.answerC: Should be made of breakable materials so they can break away in the event of a crash.
questions.answerD: Should not allow air to pass through.
questions.explanation: Face shields and goggles, being made of plastic, will develop scratches and become brittle as they age. Replace them regularly to ensure maximum protection and comfort.

questions.question: When you are riding on a bridge grating, you should:
questions.answerA: Always ride on the far right side of the lane.
questions.answerB: Always ride on the far left side of the lane.
questions.answerC: Slowly zigzag across the grating.
questions.answerD: Relax, maintain a steady speed, and ride straight across the surface.
questions.explanation: Crossing rain grooves or bridge gratings may cause your motorcycle to move in a weaving motion. This is usually not dangerous, so simply relax and proceed across the surface at a steady speed. Trying to ride at an angle to compensate for the weave is dangerous because it forces you to zigzag to stay in your lane.

questions.question: Successful motorcyclists know they are safest when they are:
questions.answerC: On the side of the road.
questions.answerD: In the left side of the lane.
questions.explanation: Successful motorcyclists know that they are safest when they are clearly seen by other road users. Use your headlight, brake light, signals, and lane position to maximize your visibility.

questions.question: If carrying a load in a sidecar, the motorcycle's stopping distance:
questions.answerC: Is not a concern.
questions.answerD: Will be similar to the stopping distance of a two-wheeled motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Because adding a load to a motorcycle increases its weight, the vehicle's inertia may increase, causing its stopping distance to increase. Begin slowing and stopping earlier when riding a motorcycle with a load or passenger in its sidecar.

questions.question: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) are designed to:
questions.answerB: Prevent brakes from activating if the roadway is dry.
questions.answerC: Apply brakes automatically.
questions.answerD: Warn you when your brake pad needs replacing.
questions.explanation: Some motorcycles are equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS). ABS is designed to prevent skidding and wheel lock-up when motorcyclists are stopping in straight-line, panic situations. ABS operates when maximum pressure is applied to both the front and rear brake controls. If electronic sensors detect the possibility of a wheel lock, brake hydraulic pressure is released then re-applied to maintain maximum braking effectiveness.

questions.question: Making eye contact with another driver:
questions.answerA: Indicates that the driver sees you.
questions.answerB: Doesn’t mean that the driver will properly yield to you.
questions.answerC: Guarantees that the other driver will properly yield to you.
questions.answerD: May make the driver mad.
questions.explanation: Never rely on eye contact as an assurance that a driver will properly yield to you. It is common for drivers to look directly at motorcyclists and still fail to notice them.

questions.question: When riding under ideal conditions, you should maintain a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerC: Three seconds.
questions.answerD: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, you should maintain a following distance of at least two seconds. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: When adjusting your rearview mirror, be sure you can:
questions.answerA: See the lane behind you and the lane next to you.
questions.answerB: See only the lane behind you.
questions.answerC: See only the lane next to you.
questions.answerD: See most of your helmet.
questions.explanation: Adjust your mirrors so you can see the lane behind you and as much as possible of the lane next to you. When properly adjusted, a mirror may show the edge of your arm or shoulder, but it’s the road behind you and to the side of you that is most important.

questions.question: Once a motorcycle helmet has been involved in a crash, it should be:
questions.answerC: Sold to another rider.
questions.answerD: Outfitted with a new chinstrap.
questions.explanation: Replace any helmet that has been worn during a crash.

questions.question: If your motorcycle begins to wobble, you should:
questions.answerC: Grip the handlebars firmly and close the throttle gradually.
questions.answerD: Downshift.
questions.explanation: Trying to accelerate out of a wobble is dangerous and will only make your motorcycle more unstable. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly (without trying to fight the wobble), gradually close the throttle to slow down, and move your weight as far forward and downward as possible. Pull off the road as soon as you can.

questions.question: When an operator's left arm is bent at the elbow and pointing upward, it means the operator:
questions.answerC: Plans to turn right.
questions.answerD: Is about to slow down.
questions.explanation: Instead of mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is bent at the elbow and pointing upward, it means the operator plans to turn right or change lanes to the right.

questions.question: If you wait an hour per alcoholic drink before you ride your motorcycle:
questions.answerA: You cannot be arrested for drinking and riding.
questions.answerB: Your skills will not be affected.
questions.answerC: Side effects may still remain.
questions.answerD: You will be fine as long as you ride slowly.
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. However, it is still possible for alcohol to accumulate in a person's system even if they consume only one drink per hour. This accumulation can still affect their ability to ride safely.

questions.question: If using a sidecar to transport a load, you should:
questions.answerA: Allow the load to move freely.
questions.answerB: Secure the load so its weight does not shift.
questions.answerC: Place the load unsecured in the seat.
questions.answerD: Secure the load near the front of the sidecar.
questions.explanation: Loads carried in a sidecar should be secured so that they do not shift and affect the motorcycle's handling. Loads should be distributed toward the rear of the sidecar to reduce tipping of the nose of the sidecar in the event of a sudden left turn.

questions.question: Compared to riding during the day, a motorcycle operator who is riding at night should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Allow more space between their motorcycle and other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Use their high beam whenever possible.
questions.answerD: Tailgate other vehicles.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision when riding at night, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use the headlights of vehicles ahead of you to see farther down the road. You should always be flexible about your lane position, especially when riding at night.

questions.question: Your lane position should:
questions.answerA: Protect your lane from other drivers.
questions.answerB: Allow you a nice view of scenery.
questions.answerC: Place you in other drivers’ blind spots.
questions.answerD: Hide your intentions from other drivers.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position can optimize a number of safety factors. Your lane position should keep you out of other vehicles’ blind spots, increase your ability to see and be seen, help you avoid surface hazards, help you avoid wind blasts from other vehicles, and provide you with an escape route from any hazards that might arise. You should be positioned in a way that discourages other drivers from trying to share your lane.

questions.question: When passing parked vehicles, motorcycle riders should be especially cautious of:
questions.answerA: Motorists looking for a place to park.
questions.answerC: Oncoming traffic.
questions.answerD: Noise.
questions.explanation: When passing parked vehicles, use caution. You may encounter vehicles pulling away from the curb or leaving parking spaces.

questions.question: When traveling at night, you can increase your ability to see by:
questions.answerA: Using the headlights of the car in front of you.
questions.answerC: Traveling at a faster speed.
questions.answerD: Decreasing your following distance.
questions.explanation: When riding at night, you can increase your line of sight by using the headlights of the vehicle in front of you to see the road ahead. Increase your following distance and reduce your speed when traveling in the dark.

questions.question: How can a motorcycle operator discourage lane sharing by other drivers?
questions.answerA: By giving dirty looks to other drivers
questions.answerB: By riding in the center portion of the lane
questions.answerC: By riding in the left portion of the lane
questions.answerD: By riding in a zigzag pattern
questions.explanation: By riding in the center portion of your lane, you will ensure that there is not a large space on either side of your motorcycle. Minimizing those spaces can help deter drivers from trying to share the lane with you.

questions.question: A DOT-approved helmet:
questions.answerA: Restricts the wearer's vision to the sides.
questions.answerB: Can greatly reduce the severity of a head injury.
questions.answerC: Is usually uncomfortable.
questions.answerD: Makes it more difficult for the wearer to control their motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Wearing a helmet while riding greatly improves your chances of avoiding serious injury to your head or neck in the case of a crash. A DOT-approved helmet will not restrict your vision to the sides.

questions.question: Making eye contact with other drivers:
questions.answerB: Guarantees that they will yield to you.
questions.answerC: Doesn’t mean that they see you.
questions.answerD: Is not worth the effort it takes.
questions.explanation: You should not rely on eye contact to guarantee that a driver will yield to you. It is not uncommon for a driver to look directly at a motorcyclist and still fail to actually notice them.

questions.question: When braking, you should use:
questions.answerC: Both front and rear brakes.
questions.answerD: Either the front or rear brake, but not both.
questions.explanation: You should always use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: Generally, the body eliminates one alcoholic drink per hour. If a person consumed eight alcoholic drinks four hours ago, how many drinks likely remain in their body?
questions.answerC: Four
questions.answerD: Five
questions.explanation: The minimum number of drinks left in a person's system can be estimated by subtracting the number of hours since the last drink from the total number of drinks consumed. In this case, the alcohol content of about four drinks would remain.

questions.question: Usually, a minimum following distance of _____ should be maintained.
questions.answerC: Three seconds
questions.answerD: Four seconds
questions.explanation: Generally, you should maintain a minimum following distance of two seconds. Increase your following distance to at least three seconds whenever you are riding under conditions that are less than ideal.

questions.question: You should increase your following distance if:
questions.answerC: You can see through the vehicle ahead of you.
questions.answerD: The sun is out.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a larger following distance.

questions.question: If you must swerve, you should:
questions.answerC: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerD: Press the handgrip in the opposite direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: If you must swerve to avoid a hazard, apply a small amount of pressure to the appropriate handle grip. To swerve to the left, press the left handle grip, then press the right to recover. To swerve to the right, press the right handle grip, then the left.

questions.question: When you park a motorcycle next to a curb, it should be:
questions.answerA: Parked at a 90-degree angle with the rear wheel touching the curb.
questions.answerB: Parked at a 45-degree angle with the front tire touching the curb.
questions.answerC: Parked like a car, with the front and rear wheels the same distance from the curb.
questions.answerD: Parked at the left edge of the parking space so approaching drivers can more easily see the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: When parking a motorcycle next to a curb, you should create at a 90-degree angle with the curb by touching your rear wheel to the curb.

questions.question: Which of the following should you inspect during a pre-ride check?
questions.answerA: The general wear and tread of your tires
questions.answerB: The amount of cushion your seat has
questions.answerC: The shine of your paint
questions.answerD: The wind direction
questions.explanation: Before setting off on any ride, you should do a thorough check of your motorcycle. Inspect the tires, oil and fluid levels, headlight, tail light, turn signals, brake light, clutch and throttle, mirrors, brakes, and horn.

questions.question: A way to lower the risk of being involved in a crash is to:
questions.answerA: Communicate your intentions to other road users.
questions.answerC: Wear dark clothes.
questions.answerD: Ride in the parts of a lane that make it difficult to be seen.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of being involved in a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: When being passed from behind, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Stay in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Move onto the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Activate your turn signal.
questions.explanation: When you are being passed from behind or by an oncoming vehicle, stay in the center portion of your lane. Riding any closer to the passing vehicle can put you in danger.

questions.question: More than half of all crashes:
questions.answerA: Occur at speeds greater than 35 mph.
questions.answerC: Happen in the dark.
questions.answerD: Involve riders who have little experience on their motorcycles.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes involve riders with little experience on their motorcycle.

questions.question: The faster you drink:
questions.answerA: The more the alcohol will accumulate in your body.
questions.answerB: The faster the alcohol is removed from your body.
questions.answerC: The more minimal the effects of the alcohol will be.
questions.answerD: The more likely you will be able to evade being pulled over.
questions.explanation: The faster you drink, the more alcohol will accumulate in your body. It is never safe to operate a motor vehicle after drinking alcohol in any amount.

questions.question: When riding with a heavy load, you will want to adjust the:
questions.answerC: Suspension.
questions.answerD: Brake light.
questions.explanation: Before riding with a heavy load, you should make sure your tire pressure, spring pre-load, air shocks, and dampers are at the settings recommended for the relevant weight.

questions.question: To swerve correctly, you should:
questions.answerC: Press the handle grip in the direction you plan to swerve.
questions.answerD: Press the handle grip in the direction opposite of where you plan to swerve.
questions.explanation: If you must swerve to avoid a hazard, apply a small amount of pressure to the appropriate handle grip. To swerve to the left, press the left handle grip, then press the right to recover. To swerve to the right, press the right handle grip, then the left.

questions.question: Which formation is best for a group of riders entering a curve?
questions.answerC: Single-file
questions.answerD: Compressed
questions.explanation: A staggered formation is generally the best way for a group to maintain close ranks while also allowing each rider to maintain an adequate cushion of space. A single-file formation is preferable when taking curves, turning, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: To stop quickly, you should:
questions.answerC: Use both brakes.
questions.answerD: Use the rear brake firmly while gradually increasing the braking pressure of the front brake.
questions.explanation: To stop quickly, apply both brakes at the same time.

questions.question: During your pre-ride inspection, you should check all of the following, except the:
questions.answerC: Turn signals.
questions.answerD: Reflectors.
questions.explanation: Before setting off on any ride, you should do a thorough check of your motorcycle. Inspect the tires, oil and fluid levels, headlight, tail light, turn signals, brake light, clutch and throttle, mirrors, brakes, and horn.

questions.question: Low-speed crashes:
questions.answerC: Rarely cause injuries.
questions.answerD: Happen frequently, so there is no need to worry about them.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes occur at speeds lower than 30 miles per hour. Even low-speed crashes can be fatal.

questions.question: If you are being chased by a dog, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop until the animal loses interest.
questions.answerC: Swerve around the animal.
questions.answerD: Approach the animal slowly, then speed up.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles often seem to attract dogs. If you are being chased by a dog, downshift and approach it slowly. Then, as you approach the dog, accelerate and leave it behind.

questions.question: How can you increase your ability to be seen at an intersection?
questions.answerA: Try to make eye contact with other drivers.
questions.answerB: Make sure you always ride using your headlight.
questions.answerC: Wave your arms.
questions.answerD: Ride closely to vehicles in front of you.
questions.explanation: To maximize your ability to be seen at an intersection, ride with your headlight on and select a lane position that provides oncoming traffic with the best view of your motorcycle. Maintain a space cushion that allows you enough space to take evasive action if a hazard arises. You should never assume that making eye contact with a driver will be enough to make them consciously register your presence.

questions.question: When choosing clothes for riding, which of the following is not a good choice?
questions.answerA: A jacket and pants that cover your arms and legs completely
questions.answerB: Boots or shoes that cover your ankles
questions.answerC: Gloves made of leather
questions.answerD: A baseball cap to cover your hair
questions.explanation: To protect yourself against injury, you should wear a DOT-compliant helmet; face or eye protection; a jacket and long pants made of sturdy material; boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles; and gloves made of durable material.

questions.question: When preparing to pass another vehicle, you should ride in the left portion of your lane because:
questions.answerA: It increases your line of sight.
questions.answerB: It decreases your line of sight.
questions.answerC: It makes it difficult to see beyond the vehicle.
questions.answerD: It allows the other driver to speed up.
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass on the left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane, both to increase your line of sight and to make yourself more visible to drivers already in the passing lane.

questions.question: You have been drinking alcohol. If you wait an hour for each drink before riding your motorcycle:
questions.answerA: You cannot be arrested for drinking and riding.
questions.answerB: Your riding skills will not be affected.
questions.answerC: Side effects from the drinking may still remain.
questions.answerD: You will be okay as long as you ride slowly.
questions.explanation: On average, the body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. However, some alcohol may accumulate in the body even if a person consumes only one drink per hour. Their abilities and judgment can still be impaired.

questions.question: Your lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerC: Avoid surface hazards.
questions.answerD: Prevent access to an escape route.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: When it starts to rain, it is usually best to:
questions.answerC: Ride in the tire tracks left by cars.
questions.answerD: Ride in the center of the lane.
questions.explanation: The center of a lane can be especially hazardous when wet. When it begins to rain, avoid the center of the road by riding in the tire tracks left by cars. The left tire track is often the best option.

questions.question: A good way to handle tailgaters is to:
questions.answerA: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerC: Use your horn and make obscene gestures.
questions.answerD: Speed up to put distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.explanation: The best way to handle a tailgater is to change lanes and let them pass you. Speeding up may cause them to tailgate you at a higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: If a tire goes flat while you are riding and you must stop, you should:
questions.answerA: Use both brakes and stop quickly.
questions.answerB: Shift your weight toward the good tire.
questions.answerC: Brake on the good tire and steer to the side of the road.
questions.answerD: Relax on the handgrips.
questions.explanation: If either of your tires go flat while you are riding, hold the handgrips firmly, ease off the throttle, and maintain a straight course. If you need to brake, gradually apply the brake to the tire that is not flat. As you slow down, edge to the side of the road, squeeze the clutch, and stop.

questions.question: When riding in a group, the best riding formation is generally:
questions.answerC: A single-file line.
questions.answerD: A pyramid formation.
questions.explanation: A staggered formation is generally best when riding in a group. You should move into a single-file line when turning, riding in a curve, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: If taking a long trip, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to minimize the number of rest breaks.
questions.answerB: Use artificial stimulants, like caffeine, if you feel drowsy.
questions.answerC: Dress warmly to avoid getting too cold during the ride.
questions.answerD: Schedule more than 12 hours of riding a day.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of fatigue on a long trip, dress to protect yourself from tiring elements, such as wind, cold, and rain. Limit yourself to no more than six hours of riding per day and take rest brakes at least every two hours. Avoid using artificial stimulants, as these only result in extreme fatigue when they wear off.

questions.question: If you are riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings and your motorcycle begins to weave, you should:
questions.answerC: Relax, maintain a steady speed, and ride straight across the grooves.
questions.answerD: Move to the leftmost portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle may weave while riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings, but this is generally not dangerous. If your motorcycle begins to weave, simply relax and proceed straight ahead at a steady speed. Trying to ride in a zigzag pattern to compensate for the weave will only increase the hazard.

questions.question: One way to tell if your rear tire has gone flat while riding is if:
questions.answerA: There is a hissing noise coming from the rear of the bike.
questions.answerB: The back end is jerking from side to side.
questions.answerC: You are unable to accelerate.
questions.answerD: The rear brake does not work.
questions.explanation: If your rear tire fails, the back of your motorcycle will likely jerk from side to side. It is rare for motorcyclists to actually hear a tire fail.

questions.question: When it is obvious that you are going to turn, you:
questions.answerA: Do not need to use a turn signal.
questions.answerB: Should still use a turn signal.
questions.answerC: Only need to use a turn signal if there are nearby pedestrians.
questions.answerD: Only need to use a turn signal if you are at a stop light.
questions.explanation: You must use proper turn signals every time you turn or change lanes, even if you think your intentions are obvious. Signals are always important, even if no one else seems to be around to see them. There may be other vehicles nearby that you can't see or haven't yet noticed.

questions.question: If your motorcycle is being chased by a dog, you should:
questions.answerC: Stop until the dog loses interest.
questions.answerD: Approach the dog slowly, then speed up.
questions.explanation: If you are being chased by a dog, downshift and approach it slowly. Then, as you approach the dog, accelerate and leave it behind. If you encounter a larger animal, brake and prepare to stop.

questions.question: If a driver is tailgating you, you should:
questions.answerC: Prevent them from passing.
questions.answerD: Move to one side of your lane to allow them to share the lane.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to get them ahead of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by encouraging them to keep tailgating you at a higher speed.

questions.question: When following a car, usually the best portion of the lane to ride in is:
questions.answerC: The right portion.
questions.answerD: The left or right portions.
questions.explanation: When riding behind a passenger vehicle, it is usually best to ride in the center of the lane so you will be visible in the driver's rearview mirror. Most drivers check their rearview mirrors much more often than their side mirrors, so this lane position will increase your chances of being seen.

questions.question: Impairment from alcohol:
questions.answerB: Begins at about half of the legal limit.
questions.answerC: Occurs at the legal limit.
questions.answerD: Occurs only if you have had multiple drinks.
questions.explanation: As little as one drink can have a significant effect on the abilities that you need for safe riding. You can be impaired even if you are well below the legal blood alcohol limit. No amount of alcohol is safe to consume before riding.

questions.question: A person with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of ______ is considered legally intoxicated.
questions.answerC: 0.08 percent
questions.answerD: 0.1 percent
questions.explanation: A person who is age 21 or older with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher is considered legally intoxicated. It is illegal and dangerous to operate any motor vehicle while intoxicated.

questions.question: To be effective, an eye or face shield must:
questions.answerC: Not allow for eyeglasses to fit underneath.
questions.answerD: Restrict your vision to the sides.
questions.explanation: To be effective, an eye or face shield must be free of scratches; be resistant to penetration; allow clear views to both sides; fasten securely; permit air to pass through to prevent fogging; and allow room for eyeglasses or sunglasses, if needed.

questions.question: When turning left, you should:
questions.answerC: Press both handgrips at the same time.
questions.answerD: Not press either handgrip.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle must lean to make a turn. To make it lean in the appropriate direction, press the handgrip in the direction you want to turn.

questions.question: When selecting footwear, you should choose:
questions.answerB: Shoes with long laces that cannot be tucked in.
questions.answerC: Shoes that cover your ankles.
questions.answerD: Shoes that are made from flimsy materials.
questions.explanation: When riding, wear boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles. Heels should be short so they don't catch on rough surfaces. Laces should be tucked in so they can't catch onto the moving parts of the motorcycle.

questions.question: A flat front tire is especially hazardous because:
questions.answerB: The front tire provides the power for the bike, so you will lose acceleration.
questions.answerC: The flat tire will shake the bike, making it hard to use the mirrors.
